subject: Re: [junit] Junit and RMI, please help ...
msgSnippet: ... It depends... If the client is a remote object, then the server will encounter a RemoteException as soon as it tries to use something from the clients
messageBody:
On Monday, April 7, 2003, at 05:24 PM, skss2002@... wrote:

> What happens if the client gets garbage collected (will this happen?)

It depends... If the client is a remote object, then the server will
encounter a RemoteException as soon as it tries to use something from
the clients remote interface*.

If the client is _not_ a remote object, then RMI provides pass by value
semantics. In other words, the server jvm gets its own copy of the
client object & the life-cycle of the original client object is
unimportant.

RMI supports/manages distributed GC. If both sides no longer reference
an object, then that object is eligble for GC. Moreover, distributed GC
rules == local GC rules. The only caveat I experienced in the
distributed scenario is that the naming service holds a reference to my
server object indefinitely. In most cases, this is probably a benefit.
(ie. you don't want your remote object/server GC'd when clients are
expecting to use it.)

-- Levi


* In my experiments toString(), equals(), and hashcode() are always
callable. These messages are serviced by the Client_Stub & don't lead
to remote communication.
